title: Book Review: The Art Of The Deal
summary:
Key ideas:
- Scott questions the effectiveness of Robert Cialdini's book on persuasion and success, Influence.
- He wonders why Cialdini wrote a book instead of using his knowledge to become more successful.
- Scott compares Cialdini with Donald Trump, who he considers a master persuader.
- He reads Trump's book, The Art of the Deal, but finds it lacking in practical advice.
- Trump's success in real estate comes from hiring the best people and knowing the right people.
- His way of solving problems is to throw the best people at it.
- Trump's interest in hotel property deals is greater than his interests in politics or anything else.
- Trump's world is narrow and does not extend beyond deals and connections.
- Trump is at risk of being interpreted as authoritarianism.

Key learnings:
- Real estate developers' key job is coordination and dealing with regulations.
- One of the developer's tricks is to lie to people in the right order to get the signatures needed.
- Trump is good at cutting through bureaucracy to get deals done.
- Trump does not have a libertarian streak and seems to accept the system he operates in.
- Trump's mindset differs from other thinkers and people who entertain the idea of an ideal system of government design.
- A-life spent overcoming obstacles and motivating good people to do their best work has been a significant part of Trump's success.
- Trump's method of problem-solving is unconventional but has worked for him.

Key questions:
- Why did Cialdini write a book instead of using his knowledge to become more successful?
- What makes Trump a master persuader, and what can be learned from his tactics?
- If Trump is good at cutting through bureaucracy, why doesn't he express discontent with the system and seek to change it?
- How Trump can utilize his skills more in the service of others, other than in his self-interest?
- How will Trump's way of thinking impact his running government if he becomes President?
- What are the qualities of Trump's style of problem-solving?
- Can Trump's governing style be interpreted as authoritarianism?
